Page 1 | Introduction 


Broadly, open research (also called ‘open scholarship’ or, in some disciplines, ‘open science’) refers to efforts to ensure that different elements of the research process are transparent and accessible. The aim of this survey is to assess the views of Oxford researchers on open research practices, related training needs and provision, and recruitment criteria.



The survey is administered by Reproducible Research Oxford. It is aimed at researchers in any role and at any career stage (including academics, research staff and fellows, research support staff, and postgraduate research students), working in any field of research across the collegiate University. The target audience includes researchers based in all Divisions of the University (Humanities; Mathematical, Physical, and Life Sciences; Medical Sciences; Social Sciences; Gardens, Libraries and Museums; Continuing Education) and/or in the Colleges.



Survey responses will inform the implementation of open research practices and responsible research assessment at Oxford. Therefore, it is important for all views to be represented. You are encouraged to take part whether or not you are aware of open research practices, and whether or not you deem them relevant or necessary for your field of research. Your participation will ensure that related guidance developed at departmental and/or University level is appropriate for your discipline.



As a ‘thank you’ for taking part, we will donate £1 to the University’s Graduate Student Support Fund for each survey submitted (up to a total of £1,500). Additionally, after completing the survey you can enter a raffle for a chance to win one of five £50 gift cards from Bookshop.org, an online service in support of local bookshops (optional; details below).



Between January and March 2021 we administered the survey to postgraduate research students. Following that round, we donated £500 to the University’s Coronavirus Hardship Fund, and we awarded five £50 Blackwell’s gift cards to respondents who entered the raffle. The results have been used to inform the work of Reproducible Research Oxford and related activities in the University, and they will be compared to the results from the current round. If you already took part in the survey, thank you for your contribution! You are welcome to take part again.



Survey procedure and data protection

Participation in the survey is voluntary. The survey comprises 12 questions, and we estimate that it will take under 20 minutes to complete. You can complete part of the survey and resume it on this device, using the same browser, within seven days. The survey will be active until 1 March 2022.



You can choose to exit the survey at any time. Additionally, you can explicitly request to withdraw your responses while the survey is active, whether you have completed it in full or only in part. Once you agree to participate, you will be provided with a respondent ID for this purpose (details below).



All responses will be anonymous and they will be used exclusively for academic purposes. Non-identifiable information will be shared openly in appropriate repositories, and relevant findings will be disseminated via the Reproducible Research Oxford website.



Once you complete the survey, you will be given access to a separate secure form. If you wish to enter the raffle for the Bookshop.org’s gift cards (optional), you can provide your contact details in this form. The information provided will not be linked to your survey responses in any way. It will be stored securely and permanently deleted once all raffle prizes are accepted. We will not use the information for any other purpose.



Reproducible Research Oxford is supported by an interdivisional award from the John Fell Fund (award number: 0007132). Ethical review of all procedures linked to the survey was conducted following Central University Research Ethics Committee (CUREC) guidance (approval number: SAME_C1A_20_105; contact: hod@anthro.ox.ac.uk), and in line with University guidance on the requirement of data protection law.

If you have any comments or questions, please contact the Reproducible Research Oxford Coordinator, Dr Malika Ihle (malika.ihle@anthro.ox.ac.uk).

This section focuses on open research. Definitions of relevant terms vary across fields of research and contexts. Therefore, we provide the following standardised entries for you to refer to throughout the remainder of the survey.

 

 
  
   
   
    Open Access publications An article, book chapter, book, or other scholarly work that is released with unrestricted access (i.e. available to the public to view online, or download, without registration, payment, or approval). This includes all forms of open access, such as 'green' (i.e. the accepted version of the work, after peer review, is shared by the author(s) in a repository), and 'gold' (i.e. the version processed by the publisher is released openly on the publisher’s system upon publication). 
    Repository A service dedicated to facilitating the preservation and sharing of research content, including digital repositories (for digital collections, data, code, etc.) and physical repositories (for collections, archives, reagents, specimens, etc.). The service may be operated by universities, governments, or private organizations, and it can be domain-agnostic or discipline-specific. Access to such repositories may be open or controlled (e.g. requiring registration, payment, or approval). Personal web-pages or other ad hoc methods of storing and sharing research content are not included.
    Data Any information underpinning a piece of research. The information can be qualitative (e.g. source, archive, representation of art, artefact) and/or quantitative (e.g. measurements, machine output, simulation results). The data can be raw (i.e. as collected), cleaned (i.e. corrected for errors), or prepared/processed (e.g. transformed into a different format for analysis, or anonymized for sharing). 
    Code Custom software developed by researchers specifically for the purpose of conducting a piece of research (e.g. a computer program to extract, clean, or analyse data, or to generate simulation results), or to build components of a research data infrastructure (e.g. a data repository). 
    Materials Any element of the research process that can be coded digitally or shared physically (e.g. protocols, survey questions, instructions, intervention materials, videos of the study procedure, specimens, reagents, samples, and other items used to collect data and/or conduct the research).
    Preprints An article, book chapter, book, or other scholarly work that is deposited in a repository ahead of peer review. Equivalent terms used in some disciplines are 'working papers' and 'unpublished manuscripts'.
    Preregistration The practice by which researchers specify elements of the planned work in a dedicated registry before observing the outcomes of the work. Examples include description of the planned approach for a qualitative study, and the data analysis plan for a quantitative study (i.e. a ’pre-analysis plan’, which can be submitted either before the start of data collection or for previously collected datasets, before the start of data analysis). 
    Registered report A journal article format in which research question(s) and methodology are peer-reviewed before the work is conducted. A submission may be provisionally accepted for publication following peer-review, and eventually published if the authors follow through with the methodology specified in the accepted version (deviations from the registered plan are allowed, but they must be explicitly justified and noted as such). Acceptance of the article to the journal is therefore independent of the results obtained.

Additionally the funds are not accessible for papers published after the project has finished, and for most of my work papers can come out up to 4 or 5 years after a funded project has officially finished. Some funders in my area e.g. Leverhulme Trust also do not allow funds to be used to pay for open access. I do put all my papers on ResearchGate and similar venues but a few publishers are very assiduous in issuing take down notices for material still under embargo.
Q4.10: It depends on what sort of OA is adopted. If it is gold OA then it will exclude people funded by groups that do not allow APCs and also colleagues in other countries where OA is not supported. This includes LMICs but I have also spoken to colleagues in France who refuse or are not permitted to pay APCs out of grants that come from public money.  Until the power of the big publishing companies is broken there will not be a fair and equitable academic publishing model. Ideally we, or our universities, should own the copyright in our formatted material and journals should be reduced to hosting platforms with no claim on intellectual property produced by academics.
Q4.14: I am just not convinced that preprints are meaningful for social science research. Most papers that I review go through significant revisions as they go from submission to publication. Reviewers and editors may also pick up on significant ethical issues related to use of qualitative data from, for example, vulnerable populations in the review processes. It feels very much like this is a methodology designed for physical and life sciences research that is not relevant or helpful for the humanities and social sciences
Q4.15: I am not sure why we would do this, or who it would benefit. I would see it mainly as a waste of time unless it was part of the evaluation process of applying for funding (i.e. unless it added a new open step to applying for grants) but even then the details of 'how' a piece of research will be conducted are not usually worked out until after funding has been secured. Also a lot of interpretation of qualitative data is inductive and only becomes clear once the researcher is actually working with the data. It is iterative and cumulative not a pre-determined deductive set of criteria.
Q4.16: Qualitative research differs in important ways from a natural sciences experiment and modulation of the research questions, protocols etc is commonplace and useful in qualitative interviews, focus groups etc so I would not welcome any approach which flags these as 'deviations' since it is hard enough to convince natural and life scientists of the validity of interpretive qualitative social science. Again I think this is a case of an approach to openness developed for physical sciences being transplanted into social sciences without really thinking through whether the assumptions that underpin it remain valid when considering social science research, especially qualitative, interpretive social science. Secondly this would either involve sharing the interview schedule etc which are already uploaded along with results to repositories like the UK Research Data Archive or it would involve writing up extra accounts of the research which is extra work on already time pressured researchers.

Q4.10:
It will likely increase publication bias, as funding for publications is not available most of the time. I probably publish 3 papers for each one that was in a grant, so who pays for those to be published? No-one us going to pay up front. 

Secondly, it changes the incentives for the publishers, probably lowering the quality they would accept, seeing as they no-longer care if anyone reads it.
Q4.11: Most of the data I use is confidential, so there are questions of anonymity. Loosening rules for access might reduce participants willingness to contribute.
Q4.12: As above, reading other peoples code is time consuming and not very helpful. It is attractive to some personalities, as they like to think they could go through code and catch people out. In reality, having to get ones code into a publishable form is more work for no benefit. Probably for most analyses it is better if they are reproduced independently, not by just copying lots of someone elses code, with it's errors. Hard to see how this helps.
Q4.14: One could imagins this undermines the business models of many journals, especially smaller ones to which libraries might not subscribe, and increases the stranglehold of larger, older journals. Not exactly an anti-trust measure.
Q4.15:
One downside is that it changes over time, and only ever gives more power to very 'stuck in a rut' types of thinking. Prospero used to take your protocol and publish it on their website. Now they 'review' it, which takes time, and decline to publish it unless you aquiesce to their changes. This is not the same thing as pre-registering, but it is what it has become, and probably an inevitable consequence of it. It is more work, as ever. 

When right heart catheterisation was invented, by a self administered procedure, there was probably no protocol registered. Who knows if someone so impetuous as to jam a catheter into their own right atrium and pulmonary vessels, for which they were fired, would have had the patience to fill out a form first? If their work had not been published as a result we would have lost this Nobel winning research. 

Another problem is that it is impossible to account for all the complexities of big data analyses until one sees the data (which one is not able to see until it is done). So one inevitably has to hedge the language of the protocol, which undermines the purpose of the thing in the first place. 

Another chilling effect of pre-registering is that people can register work, but not actually do it. No-one starts a review if there is already a protocol for it on Prospero, as they may be beaten to the punch, so it may mean the review is not ever done, or if it is done, means only one group does it. This is actually reducing reproduction of the science.
